0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: number of Factor IX international units required = body weight (kg) times desired Factor IX increase (%) times 1.2 international unit/kg
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: minor hemorrhage, (20% of normal Factor IX level), 25 to 35 international units/kg IV daily for an average of 1 day
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: moderate hemorrhage (40% of normal Factor IX level), 40 to 55 international units/kg IV daily for an average of 2 days
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: major hemorrhage, (60% or greater of normal Factor IX level), 60 to 70 international units/kg IV daily for an average of 2 to 3 days
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: minor surgery (40% to 60% of normal Factor IX level), 50 to 60 international units/kg IV one hour prior to surgery, followed by 40% of normal factor IX levels reducing to 20% over 1 to 2 weeks after surgery (55 to 25 international units/kg every 12 to 24 hours)
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: major surgery, (60% or greater of normal Factor IX level), 70 to 95 international units/kg IV one hour prior to surgery, followed by 60% of normal factor IX levels reducing to 20% over 1 to 2 weeks after surgery (70 to 35 international units/kg every 12 to 24 hours)
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: dental extractions, (40% to 60% of normal Factor IX level), 50 to 60 international units/kg IV one hour prior to extraction, for one extraction. Multiple extractions, administer for up to 1 week
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: long-term prophylaxis 20 to 30 international units/kg IV once or twice a week
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Profilnine(R) SD: number of Factor IX international units required = body weight (kg) times desired Factor IX increase (%) times 1 international unit/kg
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Profilnine(R) SD: mild to moderate hemorrhage, raise plasma factor IX level to 20% to 30% in a single administration
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Profilnine(R) SD: severe hemorrhage, raise plasma factor IX level to 30% to 50% administered daily
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Profilnine(R) SD: surgery, raise plasma factor IX level to 30% to 50% administered for at least 1 week following surgery
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Profilnine(R) SD: dental extractions, raise plasma factor IX level to 50% administered just prior to procedure and give additional doses as needed

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: number of Factor IX international units required = body weight (kg) times desired Factor IX increase (%) times 1.2 international unit/kg
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: minor hemorrhage, (20% of normal Factor IX level), 25 to 35 international units/kg IV daily for an average of 1 day
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: moderate hemorrhage (40% of normal Factor IX level), 40 to 55 international units/kg IV daily for an average of 2 days
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: major hemorrhage, (60% or greater of normal Factor IX level), 60 to 70 international units/kg IV daily for an average of 2 to 3 days
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: minor surgery (40% to 60% of normal Factor IX level), 50 to 60 international units/kg IV one hour prior to surgery, followed by 40% of normal factor IX levels reducing to 20% over 1 to 2 weeks after surgery (55 to 25 international units/kg every 12 to 24 hours)
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: major surgery, (60% or greater of normal Factor IX level), 70 to 95 international units/kg IV one hour prior to surgery, followed by 60% of normal factor IX levels reducing to 20% over 1 to 2 weeks after surgery (70 to 35 international units/kg every 12 to 24 hours)
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: dental extractions, (40% to 60% of normal Factor IX level), 50 to 60 international units/kg IV one hour prior to extraction, for one extraction. Multiple extractions, administer for up to 1 week
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Bebulin(R) VH: long-term prophylaxis 20 to 30 international units/kg IV once or twice a week
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Profilnine SD (R): number of Factor IX international units required = body weight (kg) times desired Factor IX increase (%) times 1 international unit/kg
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Profilnine(R) SD: mild to moderate hemorrhage, raise plasma factor IX level to 20% to 30% in a single administration
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Profilnine(R) SD: severe hemorrhage, raise plasma factor IX level to 30% to 50% administered daily
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Profilnine(R) SD: surgery, raise plasma factor IX level to 30% to 50% administered for at least 1 week following surgery
  • Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage: Profilnine(R) SD: dental extractions, raise plasma factor IX level to 50% administered just prior to procedure and give additional doses as needed

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Hemophilia B - Hemorrhage
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Blood coagulation disorder - Disease of liver
  • Toxicity of drug, Anticoagulant

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• factor IX complex concentrates containing high quantities of factor II, VII, or X; increased risk of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) or thrombosis
  • factor IX inhibitors, development of; increased risk for hypersensitivity reaction, including anaphylaxis
  • hepatic disease; monitor for signs of disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • hepatic disease; higher morbidity and mortality of hepatitis noted following the use of concentrated formulation in PROPLEX T(R)
  • high doses of concentrated formulation in PROPLEX T(R); greater risk of myocardial infarction, disseminated intravascular coagulation, venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism
  • human plasma contained in medication; potential risk for transmission of infection, including theoretical risk for transmission of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
  • hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis; reported for all factor IX products
  • immune-compromised patient; product may contain parvovirus B19 and/or hepatitis A
  • immune tolerance induction, attempted in patients with factor IX inhibitors and a history of allergic reactions; potential risk for nephrotic syndrome
  • latex hypersensitivity; components used in the packaging of PROPLEX T(R) contains natural rubber latex
  • newborns; higher morbidity and mortality of hepatitis noted following the use of concentrated formulation in PROPLEX T(R)
  • patients not vaccinated for hepatitis A or hepatitis B; blood or plasma containing product increases risk for development of viral infections
  • pregnancy; product may contain parvovirus B19 and/or hepatitis A
  • previously untreated patients; possibility for anaphylactic reaction following median exposure of 11 days; monitor closely from exposure day 10 to day 12
  • rapid administration (ie, greater than 10 mL/minute); increased risk for vasomotor reactions
  • strict adherence to dosing guidelines will minimize risk of thrombogenic complications
  • surgery; monitor for signs of disseminated intravascular coagulation

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Factor IX: WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Factor IX: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Factor IX complex human is derived from human plasma containing factors IX, II, VII, and X, which promotes coagulation and controls bleeding in hemophilia B patients with factor IX deficiency. Overall, all forms of factor IX achieve hemostasis through the same mechanism. A complex of factor VII and tissue factor (via the extrinsic coagulation pathway) and factor XIa (via the intrinsic pathway) activate factor IX which, in combination with factor VIII:C, activates factor X to Xa. Through this pathway, prothrombin is converted to thrombin which, in turn, converts fibrinogen to fibrin clot.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • warm to room temperature
  • use double-ended needle to transfer diluent (provided) to single-dose vial; direct flow of diluent against side of vial
  • let vial stand until contents are in solution and then swirl gently; do not shake; do not invert vial until ready to withdraw contents
  • use as soon as possible (within 3 hours) after reconstitution; discard unused portion
  • using microaggregate filter (provided), withdraw dose into syringe; discard filter
  • administer by slow infusion at a rate not exceeding: 2 mL/min Bebulin(R) VH

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• normalization of coagulation parameters
  • factor IX assays at least once daily prior to infusion; in patients with severe hemorrhage or undergoing major surgery
  • early signs and symptoms of hypersensitivity reactions; rate of administration may need to be adjusted and/or therapy discontinued
  • symptoms of infection; human plasma-derived products carry a theoretical risk of infection including viruses and the Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease agent
  • signs and symptoms of thrombosis, disseminated intravascular coagulation; especially in patients with known liver disease, surgical patients, and patients with risk factors predisposing to thrombosis

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Bebulin
    Intravenous Powder for Solution: 1 IU
  • Bebulin VH
    Intravenous Powder for Solution: 1 IU
  • Profilnine
    Intravenous Powder for Solution: 1 IU
  • Profilnine SD
    Intravenous Powder for Solution: 1 IU
